text: What's changed my mind on its likelihood is I just can't see how we get legislation through the Commons to hold EU elections. There is not the political will for it. And without that we leave with or without a deal. And as there will be no majority for a deal it's ND. I think.

text: This is right. It is certainly not a recipe for a stable country for the next few decades. There needs to be a way through this that brings moderates from both sides along with it. May is not the one to do this, it needs to be someone else. Bizarrely I think it might be Gove.

text: As a software developer I've never had a job interview that didn't come with a detailed test to ensure I knew what I was talking about. As a political pundit I've never had to prove I know anything to get on the radio or TV. It's always just my opinion. That's much easier.
author: MarkReckons

text: Quite. He'll continue to fail upwards or at worst sideways. I met him once. We were on a panel together. He blustered his way through it. Deeply unimpressive and yet his phone will always ring.
author: MarkReckons

text: But he hasn't failed. He's got a big house and a decent cv. He'll always get work. He still gets published. His privilege is still working for him big time.

text: This is true. The BBC does have a bias but it's not to any particular political persuasion per se. It's a status quo bias. That's why you very rarely hear any discussion on the BBC of whether we should have a monarchy but acres of coverage of Wills and Kate's latest trip.

text: E.g. I folded JJ to a 4BB shove when I had a similar stack in the BB but in the v next hand the player to my left was going to be forced all in for 0.6BB. I folded and the shover showed QQ. It's unusual for him to be ahead of me there but I think it was a good fold regardless.

text: I cashed last night in a live tourney and the ICM factor was pretty acute for me for most of the final table. You'd have been proud of some of my folds :)
